revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Garth Webb|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Garth Webb | image = Garth Webb.jpg | alt = Older gentleman in jacket and tie with a row of medals on his chest | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1918 | birth_place = [[Calgary]], Alberta | death_date = {{Death-date and age|May 8, 2012|1918}} | death_place = [[Burlington, Ontario|Burlington]], Ontario | nationality = Canadian | other_names = | known_for = Founding the [[Juno Beach Centre]] | occupation = }} '''Garth Webb''' (1918 – 8 May 2012) was a Canadian [[soldier]] who founded the [[Juno Beach Centre]]. Webb fought in [[World War II]] as a member of the [[Canadian 14th Field Artillery]]. He has been awarded the [[Meritorious Service Cross]] and the [[Legion of Honour]] medal.
Webb was born in [[Calgary, Alberta]] in 1918. He was educated at [[Queen's University]], and graduated from the Canadian Officers' Training Corps in 1942.<ref name="Barris">{{cite web|url=http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2012/05/14/ted-barris-garth-webbs-national-legacy/|title=Garth Webb’s national legacy|last=Barris|first=Ted|date=14 May 2012|work=National Post|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/69zJ5S16Z|archivedate=17 August 2012}}</ref> He was a lieutenant in the [[Canadian Army]] assigned to the 14th Field Artillery.<ref name="Ferenc">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/1175905--obituary-garth-webb-93-made-juno-beach-centre-a-mission|title=Obituary: Garth Webb, 93, made Juno Beach Centre a mission|last=Ferenc|first=Leslie|date=9 May 2012|work=[[Toronto Star]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/69zOJpTEV|archivedate=17 August 2012}}</ref> He fought on [[D-Day]] at the [[Juno Beach]] landings where he came ashore at [[Bernières-sur-Mer]] with his self-propelled [[M7 Priest|Priest]] artillery vehicle.<ref name="Barris" />
After the war, Webb completed a [[bachelor of Commerce|degree in commerce]] at Queen's University and moved to Toronto where he was a [[real estate appraiser]].<ref name="Nolan">{{cite web|url=http://www.thespec.com/news/local/article/721645--veteran-founded-juno-beach-centre|title=Veteran founded Juno Beach Centre|last=Nolan|first=Daniel|date=10 May 2012|work=[[The Hamilton Spectator]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/69zPSnEU5|archivedate=17 August 2012}}</ref>
Visiting the beaches of Normandy during the commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the [[Normandy Landings]], Webb noticed that there was very little to mark the efforts of Canadian troops. This spurred him to lead an effort to build the Juno Beach Centre, a museum and education centre at [[Courseulles-sur-Mer]], France.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidehalton.com/news/article/1352064--burlington-s-garth-webb-was-father-of-juno-beach-centre|title=Burlington's Garth Webb was father of Juno Beach Centre|last=Kelly|first=Tim|date=9 May 2012|work=Inside Halton|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/69zRIFJF2|archivedate=17 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macleans.ca/columnists/article.jsp?content=20030616_60922_60922|title=Garth Webb's Good War|last=Wilson-Smith|first=Anthony|date=16 June 2003|work=[[Maclean's]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/69zRMFXk2|archivedate=17 August 2012}}</ref> For his work to found the Juno Beach Centre, Webb was awarded the Meritorious Service Cross from Canada (2003) and the Legion of Honour medal from France (2005).<ref name="Ferenc" /><ref name="Tait">{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/417840271.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+04%2C+2003&author=Eleanor+Tait&pub=The+Spectator&desc=Founder+of+Juno+Beach+Centre+humbled+by+Service+Cross&pqatl=google|title=Founder of Juno Beach Centre humbled by Service Cross|last=Tait|first=Eleanor|date=4 October 2003|pages=A.09|work=[[The Hamilton Spectator]]|accessdate=17 August 2012|quote=Webb will receive the Governor General's Meritorious Service Cross.}}</ref>
Webb died on 8 May 2012 in [[Burlington, Ontario]].<ref name="Barris" /><ref name="Ferenc" /> [[Garth Webb Secondary School]] in [[Oakville, Ontario]] is named in his honour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hdsb.ca/Newsroom/SpotlightonSchools/Pages/orldWarIIveteranGarthWebbpresentedwithpictureofnewOakvillehighschool.aspx|title=World War II veteran Garth Webb presented with picture of Oakville high school|work=Halton District School Board|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/69zSapopV|archivedate=17 August 2012}}</ref>
